importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Dina Boluarte was removed from office by Congress, marking a pivotal political shift that led to the rise of interim President Jose Jeri.
The state of emergency was officially declared by Jose Jeri on this day in Lima, in response to ongoing protests and rising violence.
Dina Boluarte previously declared a 30-day state of emergency in March, which failed to curb crime, indicating a pattern of ineffective emergency measures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Interim President Jose Jeri will serve until July 2026, setting a timeline for governance during this transitional period.

keyTakeAways: Peru’s Interim President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in Lima to address sustained protests and rising crime, including extortion and homicides.
The emergency allows the government to deploy the military, restrict freedom of assembly, and suspend constitutional rights, sparking concerns over civil liberties.
Extortion cases have surged by 30% this year to 18,000, with 1,690 homicides reported between January and September 2025—up from 1,502 in 2024.
The protests are driven by Gen-Z activists demanding accountability for corruption and organized crime, leading to violent clashes that resulted in one death and over 100 injuries.
Dina Boluarte was impeached and removed from office on October 10, 2025, after failing to address the crime wave, and was succeeded by Jose Jeri as interim president.
The previous state of emergency under Boluarte in March 2025 failed to reduce crime, indicating that emergency measures alone are insufficient.
Al Jazeera’s Mariana Sanchez reported that the new emergency decree does not specify how intelligence will be gathered to combat extortion, raising transparency concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s Interim President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, to manage widespread protests driven by Gen-Z activists demanding accountability for corruption and organized crime. These protests have escalated into violence, resulting in one death and over 100 injuries. The emergency grants the government the authority to deploy the military and restrict fundamental rights, such as freedom of assembly, raising concerns over civil liberties. The decision follows the removal of former President Dina Boluarte, who was impeached for failing to address a growing crime wave, including a 30% rise in extortion cases and 1,690 homicides between January and September 2025. Despite previous emergency measures under Boluarte in March, crime has not decreased, and the current decree lacks details on how intelligence will be used to combat extortion, highlighting governance gaps.
title: State of emergency declared in Peru’s capital amid protests
